text:
The last residents of Irpin
are being evacuated

as Russian shelling of this
suburb northwest of Kyiv
intensifies.

At the drop-off point,
evacuees receive food,

tea and a bus ride
to the train station.

Among them, a stunned father
and his three children,
now suddenly motherless.

The father,
Volodomyr Skankodub,

doesn’t know where
they’ll sleep,

whether to stay with
other family members

or join the nearly
three million refugees

who have fled Ukraine 
since the war started.

And he has no information
about his wife’s body,

which they had
to leave behind.

Volunteer medics run
this three-mile stretch

many times a day to evacuate
more people from Irpin.

It’s a strategic entry point
for Russian forces

that are trying
to take the capital.

A humanitarian corridor opened
for a few days in early March,

allowing more
than 24,000 people
to be evacuated through here.

But today, there’s
no safe passage.

The mortars could hit
anywhere and anyone.

The medics stop
before a bridge

that was blown up to keep
Russian tanks from advancing

and wait for people
to hike across.

On March 6, Times reporters
recorded a shelling attack
at the same location

that killed a family
trying to flee.

Many of the evacuees
are elderly residents
who resisted leaving sooner.

The mayor of Irpin
has taken up arms

to help defend his town
and the people escaping it.
For the volunteer medics,

the work becomes more
dangerous by the day.

Three days later, Serhiy,
the ambulance driver,

shared this video
of a Russian mortar

that had exploded at
the same evacuation point
where we filmed,

wounding a
Ukrainian soldier.

Volodymyr Skakodob
and his three children

are now staying with
relatives outside of Kyiv.

He has not been able to
locate the body of his wife,
Anna Shemanskaya.
